ABSTRACT

In this work, we synthesize biocidal candidates to be used to combat marine and fluvial biofouling ‚Äì a problem capable of generating great damages and financial expenses to the hydroelectric and maritime sectors. The target products are called 1 -O-alkylgly cerols (chimyl, batyl and selachyl alcohol), and can be found in the liver oil of marine animals that do not have the biofouling process. In this work, novel synthetic strategies were developed to obtain methodologies of 1 -O- alkylglycerols, in which we use three different technologies. The first methodology involved three prepared steps: a) alkylation of the epichlorohydrin with long aliphatic alcohol; b) formation of the key intermediates 1 -O-alkylglycerophenylboronates esters through the treatment of glyc idyl ethers with phenylboronic acid and c) cleavage of cyclic 1 -O-alkylglycerophenylboronates using 1,3 -propanediol from the desired products 1, 2 and 3 with overall yields of 83, 82, 69%, respectively. In the biological tests carried out, the chimyl alcoh ol showed biocidal activity against bacteria forming the biofilm superior to copper sulfate (reference antifouling, active component of commercial marine paints) and to other synthetic intermediates 1-O-alkylglycerophenylboronates esters .

The second method ology for the synthesis of 1 -O-alkylglycerols 1, 2 and 3 involved the two preparation approaches. Using organic solvent -free reactions mediated by quaternary onium salts (N and P) and ionic liquids passing through a key hydroxyl ester intermediate, target products 1, 2 and 3 were purchased with the global yields of 95; 98; 92%, respectively. The third methodology consisted of sequential reactions in a one -pot (Tandem Method), an innovative procedure for large -scale synthesis of 1-O-alkylglycerols.

Biologica l tests on the antimicrobial activity of 1 -O-alkylglycerols were carried out at the Instituto de Estudos do Mar Almirante Paulo Moreira (IEAPM). The biocidal activity of the alkylglycerols was evaluated against four species of bacteria forming the marine b iofilm ( Vibrio communis, Pseudomonas fluorescens, Pseudoalteromonas elyakovii and Shewanella putrefaciens). The most active compounds were chimyl and batyl alcohols. Chimyl alcohol had the lowest minimum inhibitory concentration at 25 Œºg mL-1 and was more effective than copper sulphate against Vibrio communis and Pseudomonas fluorescens bacteria, demonstrating that chimyl alcohol is a potential compound to be used as a natural additive in antifouling to combat marine biofouling.

The results obtained in this thesis work allowed the publication of an article in the International Journal of Advanced Engineering Research and Science - IJAERS and the publication of the optimization of the synthesis (alluded to below) of 1 -O-alkylglycer ols in the Royal Society of Chemistry - RSC Advances, and filing of an invention patent with the National Institute of Industrial Property - INPI. Keywords: synthesis, biofouling, ethers lipids.
